petitioner.name: COMMONWEALTH OF PUERTO RICO, ET AL.

respondent.name: FRANKLIN CALIFORNIA TAX-FREE TRUST, ET AL.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next in Case 15-233, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico v. Franklin California Tax-Free Trust and the consolidated case. Mr. Landau. ORAL ARGUMENT BY CHRISTOPHER LANDAU ON BEHALF OF THE PETITIONERS

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Landau, that's true. Don't you run up against, with respect to the Puerto Rico -- Puerto Rico's legislation, the Contract Clause, the -- the bar against impairing contracts; that Puerto Rico can't impair the lenders' contracts? So apart from -- so if there's -- if we're dealing only with the Puerto Rico legislation, doesn't that, in -- in requiring nonconsenting lenders to give up or have their claims reduced, Puerto Rico is violating the Contract Clause?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Why would Congress preclude Puerto Rico from Chapter 9? In other words, what -- what is the background of this provision?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Is there any compact with those other Territories that precludes them from using their Territorial power to reorganize their debts?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I know that Guam and the Virgin Islands have Federal courts.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And they have Federal judges. Are they subject to constitutional provisions? Is it an open question of whether they are subject to the Contract Clause as well? To the contract provision limitation, I should say?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, that's the open issue that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- has to go on remand.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Landau, could I ask you to focus on the text here a little bit? Because this gateway theory of yours, I'm not sure it matches up with Alderson Reporting Company the text very well. I mean, you could have a gateway provision which said something like, Puerto Rico is a State for all purposes except Chapter 9, or except for any provision in Chapter 9, or something like that. But Chapter -- but this provision, 101(52), is written much more specifically. It says except for the purpose of defining who may be a debtor under Chapter So it's not any provision in Chapter 9; it's just for the purpose of defining who may be a debtor.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Mr. Landau, I'm not sure I understand that argument, so you're going to have to back up a minute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: It's, I think, critical to your point, which is, Justice Kagan asked a direct question: Why couldn't Congress have said much more directly, under 101, the term "State" includes the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico except for Chapter 9?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: If Puerto Rico is not a State for Chapter 9, then it couldn't have authorized its municipality to file under It would have reached the same end, but more clearly saying that Puerto Rico is not a State.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But then it has two other clauses which are the key clauses.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And the trouble that I have is where it says --  the same problem that Justice Kagan raised. I mean, you have a statute that prohibits importing a vegetable that isn't a fish, and we can't read "vegetable" as "fish." I mean, it just isn't. And what I'm having is the problem of the language.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Let --  let me show you. Alderson Reporting Company The term "State," just as she said it, includes the District of -- of Columbia and Puerto Rico.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Where do we find that? In the first part of Title 11, which has to do with bankruptcy. So what it seems to be doing is it's the whole Bankruptcy Code. It's So when I see the word "State," that includes Puerto Rico. And then it says, "except for the purpose of defining who may be a debtor under Chapter 9." So I go back, I look at it, and it says -- one of the things, it says, well, a State law prescribing a method of composition of indebtedness. That is not for the purpose of defining who is a debtor under -- under Chapter So what am I supposed to do about that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What the first part of the tree says is, State, nothing we say really stops you from controlling your municipality, except in one important respect.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And the important respect is that you cannot have your own bankruptcy law. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yeah.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But I read it as a decision tree. What am I supposed to say?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I know that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: They can't be a debtor.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So --  so then where -- where --  where in the Code, except for this provision -- are there dozens of places? 20? A thousand? --  where the word "State" is used outside of Chapter 9's debtor provisions where then it makes sense to read Puerto Rico into it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: About 40?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And you have them in your brief? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no, but I -- is there some reference? I can get them?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But in all those provisions, debtor, creditor, State play active roles in implementing the provisions of those chapters.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So in all the other places, the State is involved --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- by -- inherent in the definition of what a debtor and what a creditoror is, the State has rights and responsibilities under those provisions.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What you -- what I'm understanding you to say is, Puerto Rico has been kicked out of Chapter altogether. It doesn't even get into the gateway.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And so to read it as Alderson Reporting Company being involved as a State, the only other place that's used is here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: In 903, you have to be part of it in some way.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Mr. Landau, this is not very different from what we did in -- last year in Utility Air Regulatory Group v. the EPA. We had one general definition of a statutory term, and then we Alderson Reporting Company looked at it and its play within other sections, and we said can't be given the same meaning, because the definition applies to one generalized feature of the Act, and the use here is in a more specialized way.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But you didn't cite Utility Air. Is there a reason you didn't?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All I have to do is to get myself to do the following thing: I could dress it up so people couldn't understand it. But what I would be doing is saying the following: It says a State law, and it says the chapter does not limit or impair the power of a State, okay, et cetera, et cetera.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, all I have to say is that word "State" right there does not include Puerto Alderson Reporting Company Rico.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: My only problem with writing those words is somebody is going to direct me to the provision a little bit later where it says the word "State" in Title 11, of which this is part, means Puerto Rico. Okay?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, that --  that's hard for me to do because of that language.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That may be, but I can't say that an "airplane" means a horse. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: So, Mr. Landau, I -- I think I get what you're saying now, which I didn't when I started with. You're saying they couldn't just say it's a State, except for purposes of Chapter 9, because, in fact, there's something that's outside of Chapter that determines who gets into Chapter So what they did was they said it's a State, except for purposes of this gateway, and then they assumed that that meant that all of Chapter wouldn't apply either. That's your basic argument.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: So -- but before 1984, before this amendment, this 903(1) did apply to Puerto Rico; wasn't that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: So you're saying that the really super significant change, which is 903(1) applies to Puerto Rico before 1984, and then doesn't apply after because of this definitional move that they made here in 101(52). What you have to admit is -- I'm not quite sure what the -- the word -- I mean, it's a -- it would be a mysterious way, it would be an extremely kind of cryptic odd way to make such a major change.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I mean, it's almost like somebody doesn't want everybody to recognize what a major change is being made --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- and figured out this way that is -- where nobody would understand that that was happening, including the judges who would have to decide what this meant. (Laughter.) Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Please.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, that's --  I mean, that's your basic policy argument, and I'm not sure it carries much weight. Why --  why would it be irrational for Congress to say, all right, this is the system we're going to apply to all the States, but when it comes to Puerto Rico, if they want changes, we want them to come to us, partly because Congress has a different sort of relationship with Puerto Rico than it has to all the other States?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Why not treat it like -- why not treat it like every other Territory?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That's the mouse in -- that's the mouse in --  in the hole --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: --  which is if you're going to treat it differently, wouldn't you expect them to say that? We're going to treat it not like a State and not like a Territory. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And that's a very -- you came up with a very good answer, Mr. Landau, to my question. But I wonder why it's absurd to treat the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico different from Guam and the -- the Virgin Islands. I mean, why would you lump those two -- those four together?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Have you given up the Government Development Bank's position and that of some of the amici that the provision of 903(1) applies to States only when a debtor is in a Chapter proceeding because of that provision use of creditor?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Are you rejecting the argument?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. McGill.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, no State has possessed the power to impair contract rights under the Constitution. Nothing about the Bankruptcy Code changes Alderson Reporting Company the application of the Contract Clause. They have to go into Chapter to impair contracts --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: --  in a meaningful way, correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right. So what makes you think that Congress intended to let Puerto Rico and the District of Columbia have free reign in whatever they wanted to do? Wouldn't they be subject, in your judgment --  I'm sure you'd be arguing they're subject to the Contract --  Impairment Clause.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Exactly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So you think Congress intended to stop Puerto Rico and the District of Columbia from passing emergency legislation that said don't shut off the lights tonight; that --  that Congress intended that that kind of temporary provision could only be subject to Congress, who may be on recess, who might be wherever it is, that it could not do that? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, it decided to overrule it by giving States the opportunity to go into bankruptcy, and that would be a temporary state to start with.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And it never gave --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And it never gave the Territories that. So the Territories can pass a law that stops the lights from going out today until Congress comes into effect, 'cause it can't do a permanent impairment of the contract.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Doesn't the definitional section of the Code tell you who qualifies as a debtor, who qualifies as a creditor, who can go into what chapter or not? It tells you if you're this kind of creditor, you go into that chapter. If you're that kind of creditor, you go -- I'm sorry. If you're this kind of debtor, you go to -- individual goes here, business goes there, this one goes here. You have options. Isn't it what he describes as a gateway that tells you where you're a part or what you're a part of?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Oh, but it is, because it tells you what kind of debtors can make use of what Alderson Reporting Company kind of provision.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: It is always. That's what the purpose of a gateway is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So if the -- if the definitional section defines "State" to include Puerto Rico, and you say even though it's not a part of Chapter by definition in 109, it still remains a State for purposes of this reservation of State powers? Why aren't we using "creditor" in as it's used in the Bankruptcy Code?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: If you're going to be literal as to "State," why aren't you literal as to "creditor"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But let's go back. If you're going to take the literal meaning of "State" definitionally, why aren't you taking the literal meaning of "creditor"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So how do I read into the statute? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, you actually can't do that, meaning you can't do that according to our prior precedent. It is inherent in State sovereignty that States have to have some method, their own method, of controlling their municipalities. You can have uniform bankruptcy laws, but if you don't make them available to a municipality because the State hasn't approved it, can you rob a State under State sovereignty of all power to regulate its municipality and to save it from -- from bankruptcy?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Actually, so why do so many major commentators, bankruptcy writers, district and circuit courts, the Sixth Circuit included, have said that that's impossible; that you can't rob a State of the power to regulate its municipalities if you're offering it nothing in return?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And then we said in Faitoute that you can't force States --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- to go into bankruptcy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. McGill --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Can I talk to you about Mr. Landau's textual argument? Because I came in here thinking that your best argument is straight on the text. It's not about purpose, because I don't know what Congress's purpose here was; it's not on policy. It's just straight on the text. But I now have a better understanding of Mr. Landau's understanding of the text, and so I just want to engage you on that, which is: Look, Congress couldn't have just said "except for purposes of Chapter 9" because of this flukey thing, which is that the gateway provision is outside of Chapter So if it had just said "except for purposes of Chapter 9," somebody could have said, oh, well, look, I am entitled to be a debtor under Chapter 9, whether or not I'm thought of as a State. And so they did it this other way, which said -- which attacked the gateway provision particularly. And then in doing that, they assumed that all of Chapter would follow in its wake. Once you're not eligible for Chapter 9, none of the provisions of Chapter apply to you. That's Alderson Reporting Company basically Mr. Landau's provision -- argument. So tell me why that's wrong.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But it doesn't have to be just that. He has some -- an additional string to the bow; that is, what he wants us to do is to take the words "a State" -- "this chapter does not limit or impair the power of a State," which is in Now, he wants us to read that as if there were then a parentheses, "a State that is a debtor under Chapter 9." You see? And that a State -- what States? The States that can be debtors under Chapter Now, that's how he wants us to read it, and that means that that provision does not apply to Puerto Rico or D.C. But it isn't just that no part of Alderson Reporting Company Chapter could apply to them. It is that if you look at the first sentence of 903, is that what it says is that those States that are referred to in that first sentence maintain all the power to control by legislation or otherwise a municipality. And he says, what could that apply to? Those entities that are not in Chapter obviously have all the powers they normally had, but the ones that are in Chapter might not. And so what this Section is addressed to are those States that are in Chapter 9, because there's no need to apply that first sentence to anyone else, and therefore it doesn't apply to Puerto Rico, that first sentence. But since the key sentences, one and two, are subparts of the first sentence, they don't apply, either. I think that's the whole argument. And it isn't requiring us to really play that much -- you don't play games with the words. All you do is say, this is one of those parts of Chapter -- not all, but one of those parts -- that even though it doesn't use the word "debtor" under Chapter 9, applies only to debtors under Chapter I think that's the argument I got, and is that -- that's, I think, probably consistent with what Justice Kagan was saying.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You got it? Do you see what I'm saying?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Good. All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But not -- no. In -- my guess is, if we go through Chapter 9, and the parts that will -- do apply to debtors under Chapter --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- whoa, whoa, whoa -- municipalities. State municipalities. If we go through Chapter and look at those portions of Chapter that do apply to municipalities who are there legitimately as debtors, we will find some sentences that clearly apply only to those who are in there as debtors and clearly do not apply to anyone else in the world. And he is saying this is one of those. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. McGill, why would Congress put Puerto Rico in this never-never land? That is, it can't use Chapter 9, and it can't use a Puerto Rican substitute for Chapter It's locked out by the provision on which you are relying, so it has to take the bitter, but it doesn't get any benefit at all. Why in the world -- what explains Congress wanting to put Puerto Rico in this anomalous position of not being able to restructure its debt?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, Mr. --  Mr. McGill, if I could go back to Justice Breyer's question, because Justice Breyer gave you a view of the way to read this text, which is built on Mr. Landau's view, and said, what's wrong with that? And you --  you go with the gateway provision, and then even if not all of Chapter follows in its wake, at least all the provisions in Chapter that refer to debtors follow in its wake. And Justice Breyer said, what's wrong with that, as a way to read this text. And then you answered him, I think this is fair to say, by giving a --  a story about what Congress meant to do in 903(1) in the wake of Faitoute. But, you know, both of you have stories about this, and it's not --  just not clear which of you is right. And I guess what I most want to think about is this text. Why isn't Justice Breyer's, Mr. Landau's view of the text just as good, if not better, than yours? And I didn't come in here thinking that, but now I kind of am thinking that. So talk to me about the text, why that's not just as good a view of the text?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But that's --  that's a purpose that tells you whether you're now in Chapter as a debtor.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: So what Mr. Landau is saying is once you say you're --  you're --  you're not a State, when it comes to who may be a debtor under Chapter 9, that it's a pretty natural thing to say, and that means that any provisions about being a debtor under Chapter don't apply to you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But that's up to the State. It's up to the State to make that decision. Puerto Rico isn't given that option.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. So you're saying is --  I take it you're --  that you say -- you say --  you're just used to this. So you don't understand that I'm not used to it. And the --  the -- you --  you go look at There --  there are three separate sentences. And you're saying that the --  the first sentence and second and third are really separate things. That number and 3, which are numbered and 2, have a big objective. If I read the cases you cite, I will say Congress intended something very clear. They didn't want those States who weren't in Chapter They didn't want those States who were not in Chapter They Alderson Reporting Company didn't want them to make rules for bankruptcy of municipalities, not binding rules, anyway. That was their purpose. And there's just no reason to think that when they had the specific thing before, they wanted somehow to let Puerto Rico and District of Columbia do it, do what the States couldn't do.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And you say, well, there is a good reason. They said the good reason is the States can come in to 9, and they can't. And you say, well, that isn't a good enough reason. Is that where -- have I got this?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Referencing that, can you give me one more thing? Give me your best either Law Review article, treatise, legislative history, whatever it is, that will -- that will show me that, in your view, look, these are separate things. This -- the Alderson Reporting Company first sentence was not meant to be just a gateway into -- into and 2, that -- that it was designed to do what you say. What do I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So you believe that the Alderson Reporting Company States that don't permit their municipality to become debtors are limited in what they can do by 903? In other words, their --  their municipalities are not debtors? Their sovereign powers have been cut off? They cannot reorganize the debt except through Chapter 9? Then we're talking about a coercive provision. We're saying you can't do anything about the composition of your debt. If percent of the creditors want to reorganize their debt with you and those percent vultures are saying no, and a Court would say it's not an impairment of a contract to redo this debt because of the need, everything else that we've said in the past, you're saying States can't do it if -- if --  they can only do it under Chapter 9?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Assume --  I assume it doesn't. Assuming. You're saying intended to preclude States, solvent States and solvent municipalities, it --  it intended to stop States from Alderson Reporting Company doing any reorganization of any debt, even if it doesn't impair the contract clause, it can't do it until every creditor approves, whether or not their municipality is in Chapter or not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right. And what's not coercive about that? What's the choice for States that Congress is giving?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: It's like the Tenth Amendment right of States to deal with their municipalities consistent with the Constitution. Where does that leave --  you can make uniform-bankruptcy laws, but nothing about that permits you to impair the rights of States so drastically?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Isn't there also legislation to put Puerto Rico back in Chapter 9?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Landau, you have four minutes remaining.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
